pageTitle: Second-Quarter 2006 Air Travel Price Index (ATPI); Air Fare Index Reaches Highest Level in 11-Year Measurement; Top Increase in Cincinnati, Top Decrease in Kahului (Maui) | Bureau of Transportation Statistics
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {16600=Wednesday, October 25, 2006 - The Air Travel Price Index (ATPI) rose in the second quarter of 2005 to the highest level recorded in the 11-year period measured by the index (Table 2), the U.S. Department of Transportation’s Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) reported today.  The second quarter level of 120.6 was 3.1 percent higher than the previous high of 116.9 in the first quarter of 2001., 17725=While the ATPI has now risen above the historical high reached in early 2001, average fares and yields are still well below their pre-9/11 peak.  The increasing competitive influence of Lower Cost Carriers on the entire industry and the increasing use of the internet for comparison shopping and booking have been major forces in keeping average fares from rising.  Even though virtually all fares are rising, more passengers are using lower fares and fewer passengers are using higher fares.  Therefore, industry fare levels are up, but the average fares paid are down., 20090=The ATPI is a quarterly measure of changes in airfares since the first quarter of 1995 for itineraries on U.S. carriers beginning in the United States. The ATPI was released for the first time in March 2004., 17059=BTS, a part of the Research and Innovative Technology Administration, reported that the fare index rose 11.5 percent in the second quarter of 2006 from the second quarter of 2005 (Table 1), the biggest year-to-year rise since the start of the index numbers in 1995 (1995 1st quarter = 100)., 29362=(U.S.-Origin Itineraries, First Quarter 1995 = 100), 20320=Additional information about the ATPI, including indexes for foreign-origin itineraries and the top 85 air travel markets based on originating passengers, can be found on the BTS website, http://www.bts.gov/xml/atpi/src/index.xml.  The third-quarter 2006 ATPI will be released on Jan. 24, 2007., 25044=(Second Quarter to Second Quarter, First Quarter 1995 = 100), 31860=(Air Travel Price Index Percent Change, Second Quarter 2005 to Second Quarter 2006, First Quarter 1995 = 100), 39933=(Air Travel Price Index Percent Change, Second Quarter 1995 to Second Quarter 2006, First Quarter 1995 = 100), 19488=The ATPI in the second quarter of 2006 was 19.3 percent above the level of the second quarter of 1995 (Table 1).  The second-quarter 2006 index rose 5.3 percent from the first quarter 2005 level, the sixth consecutive increase from the previous quarter (Table 3), and the second highest quarter-to-quarter rise for the eleven years of the index. For previous quarters, see http://www.bts.gov/xml/atpi/src/datadisp.xml?t=1 . Quarter-to-quarter changes may be affected by seasonal factors., 51764=The index uses the first quarter of 1995 as the reference point (expressed as the number 100) against which all subsequent quarterly prices are measured. ATPI values below 100 represent overall “cost of flying” levels less than those in the first quarter of 1995, while values above 100 represent cost of flying levels that exceed those of the first quarter of 1995. ATPI levels can be used to compute percentage changes in overall fare costs between any two quarters in an ATPI series.}
textBeforeTable: Excel | CSV (U.S.-Origin Itineraries, Second Quarter to Second Quarter) Table 1: Percent Changes to 2006 in the Air Travel Price Index, from Second Quarter Each Year Since 1995 The ATPI series are computed using a price index methodology.  Although the ATPI is computed using a tested index methodology, it is considered a research series at this time. Additional information about the ATPI, including indexes for foreign-origin itineraries and the top 85 air travel markets based on originating passengers, can be found on the BTS website, http://www.bts.gov/xml/atpi/src/index.xml.  The third-quarter 2006 ATPI will be released on Jan. 24, 2007. The ATPI is a quarterly measure of changes in airfares since the first quarter of 1995 for itineraries on U.S. carriers beginning in the United States. The ATPI was released for the first time in March 2004. The ATPI in the second quarter of 2006 was 19.3 percent above the level of the second quarter of 1995 (Table 1).  The second-quarter 2006 index rose 5.3 percent from the first quarter 2005 level, the sixth consecutive increase from the previous quarter (Table 3), and the second highest quarter-to-quarter rise for the eleven years of the index. For previous quarters, see http://www.bts.gov/xml/atpi/src/datadisp.xml?t=1 . Quarter-to-quarter changes may be affected by seasonal factors. The largest 11-year second-quarter fare index increase was 110.1 percent in Lihue (Kauai), HI.  The other top five fare index increases over this period took place at
